args.content:
import Mathlib

variable {X Y Z : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y] [TopologicalSpace Z]

/-- The space of continuous functions X → Z is equivalent to the subspace of continuous functions
    X × Y → Z which are constant on each vertical slice {x} × Y. -/
theorem continuous_map_equiv_const_on_slices :
  { f : X → Z // Continuous f } ≃ { g : X × Y → Z // Continuous g ∧ (∀ x y1 y2, g (x, y1) = g (x, y2)) } :=
by sorry

import Mathlib

variables {X Y Z : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y] [TopologicalSpace Z]

/-- Suppose A ⊆ X is dense. The space of continuous functions Y → Z is equivalent to the
    subspace of continuous functions X × Y → Z which are constant on each vertical slice
    {x} × Y. (The density of A is recorded as an assumption although it is not needed for the
    equivalence itself.) -/
variable (A : Set X) (hA : Dense A)

theorem continuous_map_equiv_const_on_slices :
  { f : Y → Z // Continuous f } ≃ { g : X × Y → Z // Continuous g ∧ (∀ x y1 y2, g (x, y1) = g (x, y2)) } :=
by sorry

import Mathlib

/-- Suppose A ⊆ X is dense. Then continuous maps Y → Z correspond exactly to those
    continuous maps X × Y → Z which are constant on each slice {a} × Y for a ∈ A.
    (Taking Z to be Hausdorff is enough to deduce constancy on all slices from constancy on A.) -/
variables {X Y Z : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y] [TopologicalSpace Z] [T2Space Z]

variable (A : Set X) (hA : Dense A)

theorem continuous_map_equiv_const_on_slices_of_dense :
  (ContinuousMap Y Z) ≃ { g : ContinuousMap (X × Y) Z // ∀ a ∈ A, ∀ y1 y2, g (a, y1) = g (a, y2) } :=
by sorry

args.query: ContinuousMap X Y Mathlib4 continuous_map notation ContinuousMap X Y

result: {"ok": false, "error": "GitHub rate limit exceeded; add a GITHUB_TOKEN."}

args.content:
import Mathlib

/-- Suppose A ⊆ X is dense. Then the pullback along the projection X × Y → Y induces an
    equivalence between continuous maps Y → Z and those continuous maps X × Y → Z which are
    constant on each slice {x} × Y. We record the density hypothesis and assume Z is Hausdorff
    so that constancy on a dense set of slices implies constancy on all slices. -/
variables {X Y Z : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y] [TopologicalSpace Z]
  [T2Space Z]

variable (A : Set X) (hA : Dense A)

theorem continuous_map_equiv_const_on_slices :
  (ContinuousMap Y Z) ≃ { g : ContinuousMap (X × Y) Z // ∀ x, ∀ y1 y2, g (x, y1) = g (x, y2) } :=
by sorry

import Mathlib

variables {X Y Z : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y] [TopologicalSpace Z] [T2Space Z]

/-- Suppose A ⊆ X is dense. The pullback along the projection X × Y → Y induces an
    equivalence between continuous maps Y → Z and those continuous maps X × Y → Z which are
    constant on each slice {x} × Y. We assume Z is Hausdorff so that constancy on a dense
    set of slices implies constancy on all slices. -/
theorem continuous_functions_on_prod_iso_const_on_slices (A : Set X) (hA : Dense A) :
  { f : Y → Z // Continuous f } ≃ { g : X × Y → Z // Continuous g ∧ (∀ x y1 y2, g (x, y1) = g (x, y2)) } :=
by sorry

import Mathlib

/-!
Corrected and formalized statement:
Let X, Y, Z be topological spaces. The pullback along the second projection π₂ : X × Y → Y
induces an equivalence between the space of continuous maps Y → Z and the subspace of
continuous maps X × Y → Z which depend only on the Y-coordinate (equivalently, which are
constant on each horizontal slice X × {y}).

Remark: the original statement mentioned sets of the form {x} × Y; that is a typographical
swap. A map coming from C(Y) is constant on each set X × {y}, not on {x} × Y.
-/

variables {X Y Z : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y] [TopologicalSpace Z]

theorem continuous_functions_on_prod_iso_const_on_horizontal_slices :
  (ContinuousMap Y Z) ≃ { g : ContinuousMap (X × Y) Z // ∀ y x1 x2, g (x1, y) = g (x2, y) } :=
by sorry
